part.parttext: Human Rights Commission and Advisory Council

subsection.subsectiontext: The British Columbia Human Rights Commission is established consisting of the following members appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council:

paragraph.paragraphtext: a chief commissioner;
a deputy chief commissioner;
a commissioner of investigation and mediation.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3), the members appointed under subsection (1) hold office for a term of 5 years.
The first appointment of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the deputy chief commissioner is to be for a term of 3 years, and
the commissioner of investigation and mediation is to be for a term of 4 years.

subsection.subsectiontext: The chief commissioner is eligible to be reappointed for one additional term of 5 years.
The deputy chief commissioner and the commissioner of investigation and mediation are eligible to be reappointed for one or more additional terms of 5 years.
The chief commissioner is the chief executive officer of the commission and must

paragraph.paragraphtext: subject to subsection (8), supervise and direct the work of the commission and its staff, and
preside at meetings of the commission.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the chief commissioner is absent or incapacitated or if that office is vacant,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the deputy chief commissioner may act as the chief commissioner during the absence, incapacity or vacancy, and
the deputy chief commissioner may exercise all of the powers and may perform all of the duties and functions of the chief commissioner.

subsection.subsectiontext: The chief commissioner and the deputy chief commissioner must not direct or interfere with the exercise of any power granted to or duty imposed on the commissioner of investigation and mediation under this Code.
A memeber of the commission who is not an employee under the Public Service Act may be paid the remuneration set by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
A member of the commission is to be reimbursed for reasonable travelling and out of pocket expenses necessarily incurred in discharging the member's duties.
Employees necessary to carry out the powers and duties of the commission may be appointed under the Public Service Act.
The commission may engage or retain consultants and specialists that the commission considers necessary to carry out the powers and duties of the commission and may determine their remuneration.
The Public Service Act does not apply to the retention, remuneration or engagement of consultants and specialists under subsection (2).

As soon as practicable after the end of the fiscal year of the government, the chief commissioner must submit to the minister an annual report on the activities of the commission and the disposition of complaints under this Code during the preceding year.
The annual report must include information concerning compliance with the regulations made under section 49 (2) (b).

The minister must promptly lay the report before the Legislative Assembly if it is in session or, if it is not in session when the report is submitted, within 15 days after the beginning of the next session.

The chief commissioner may submit a special report to the minister concerning any matter regarding human rights in British Columbia that the chief commissioner considers to be of such urgency or importance that it cannot be deferred until the next annual report under section 18.

The minister must promptly lay the special report before the Legislative Assembly if it is in session or, if it is not in session when the report is submitted, within 15 days after the beginning of the next session.

The Human Rights Advisory Council is established consisting of at least 7 and not more than 11 members appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council for a term set by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council must designate one of the members as chair of the advisory council to preside at meetings of the council.
The role of the advisory council is to

paragraph.paragraphtext: inform the public about the work of the commission,
ensure that the concerns of the public are brought to the attention of the commission, and
advise the commission and the minister on matters relevant to the administration of this Code.

subsection.subsectiontext: The advisory council must not provide advice under subsection (3) (b) or (c) concerning a specific complaint before the commission or tribunal.
A member of the advisory council may be paid the remuneration set by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
A member of the advisory council is to be reimbursed for reasonable travelling and out of pocket expenses necessarily incurred in discharging the member's duties.

subsection.subsectiontext: The commissioner of investigation and mediation may designate an employee appointed under section 17 (1), or any other person, as a human rights officer for the purpose of conducting investigations of complaints.

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purpose of investigating a complaint, the commissioner of investigation and mediation or a human rights officer may

paragraph.paragraphtext: require the production of books, documents, correspondence or other records that relate or may relate to the complaint, and
make any inquiry relating to the complaint of any person, in writing or orally.

subsection.subsectiontext: If a person refuses to

paragraph.paragraphtext: comply with a demand under subsection (1) (a) for the production of books, documents, correspondence or other records, or
respond to an inquiry made under subsection (1) (b),

section.subsandwich: the commissioner of investigation and mediation or a human rights officer may apply to the Supreme Court for an order requiring the person to comply with the demand or respond to the inquiry.

subsection.subsectiontext: A judge of the Supreme Court, on application under subsection (2), may

paragraph.paragraphtext: make an order requiring a person to

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: produce a book, document, correspondence or other record to the commissioner of investigation and mediation or a human rights officer under subsection (1) (a), or
respond to an inquiry made under subsection (1) (b), and

paragraph.paragraphtext: make any other order that the judge considers necessary to enforce the demand or inquiry under subsection (1).

subsection.subsectiontext: For the purpose of investigating a complaint, the commissioner of investigation and mediation or a human rights officer may, with the consent of the owner or occupier, enter and inspect any premises that in the opinion of that commissioner or the human rights officer may provide information relating to the complaint.
A person exercising a power of entry under subsection (4) must, on request, produce identification and give reasons for requiring entry to the premises.

If consent to enter any premises is withheld by the owner or occupier under subsection (4), the commissioner of investigation and mediation or a human rights officer must not enter the premises unless authorized by a warrant under subsection (7).

A justice, if satisfied by information on oath or affirmation that access to any premises is necessary for the purposes of an investigation under section 23, may issue a warrant authorizing a person named in the warrant to enter and inspect those premises.

If a justice is satisfied by information, on oath or affirmation, that there are in a place books, documents, correspondence or other records that there are reasonable and probable grounds to believe will afford evidence relevant to a complaint, the justice may issue a warrant authorizing a person named in the warrant to

paragraph.paragraphtext: search the place for those books, documents, correspondence or records, and
remove those books, documents, correspondence or records for the purpose of making copies of them.

subsection.subsectiontext: If books, documents, correspondence or other records are produced under subsection (1) (a) or removed under subsection (8) (b), the commissioner of investigation and mediation or a human rights officer must

paragraph.paragraphtext: copy the books, documents, correspondence or records as quickly as possible, and
promptly return the books, documents, correspondence or records to the person who produced them or to the place from which they were removed.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the commissioner of investigation and mediation determines that another proceeding is capable of appropriately dealing with the substance of a complaint, the commissioner may, at any time before the complaint is referred to the tribunal for a hearing, defer further consideration of the complaint until the outcome of the other proceeding.
In making a determination under subsection (2), the commissioner of investigation and mediation must consider all relevant factors including

paragraph.paragraphtext: the subject matter and nature of the other proceeding, and
the adequacy of the remedies available in the other proceeding in the circumstances.

subsection.subsectiontext: After

paragraph.paragraphtext: determining, under section 23 (2), that a complaint can be disposed of without an investigation, or

section.subsandwich: the commissioner of investigation and mediation must

paragraph.paragraphtext: refer all or part of the complaint to the tribunal for a hearing, or
dismiss all or part of the complaint under section 27.

subsection.subsectiontext: If, after determining under section 23 (2) that a complaint can be disposed of without an investigation, the commissioner of investigation and mediation determines that an investigation is necessary before action can be taken under subsection (1) (c) or (d), that commissioner may investigate the complaint or may assign a human rights officer to investigate the complaint.

If, after receiving the report of a human rights officer under section 23 (3), the commissioner of investigation and mediation determines that further investigation of the complaint is necessary before action can be taken under subsection (1) (c) or (d), that commissioner may continue with the investigation or assign a human rights officer to continue with the investigation.

The commissioner of investigation and mediation must provide the parties with a copy of any investigation report submitted under section 23 (3) and of any results of an investigation under subsection (2) or (3) of this section.

If the commissioner of investigation and mediation refers all or part of the complaint to the tribunal for a hearing under subsection (1) (c), that commissioner must inform the following persons of that decision in writing:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the parties;
if not already a party, the deputy chief commissioner.

change.changenote: Section 27 BEFORE amended by 2002-62-12, effective March 31, 2003 (BC Reg 79/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: The commissioner of investigation and mediation may, at any time after a complaint is filed, dismiss all or part of the complaint if that commissioner determines that any of the following apply:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the complaint or that part of the complaint is not within the jurisdiction of the commissioner of investigation and mediation;
the acts or omissions alleged in the complaint or that part of the complaint do not contravene this Code;
there is no reasonable basis to justify referring the complaint or that part of the complaint to the tribunal for a hearing;
proceeding with the complaint or that part of the complaint would not

subparagraph.subparagraphtext: benefit the person, group or class alleged to have been discriminated against, or
further the purposes of this Code;

paragraph.paragraphtext: the complaint or that part of the complaint was filed for improper motives or made in bad faith;
the substance of the complaint or that part of the complaint has been appropriately dealt with in another proceeding;

the contravention alleged in the complaint or that part of the complaint occurred more than one year before the complaint was filed unless the complaint or that part of the complaint was accepted under section 22 (3).

subsection.subsectiontext: In making a determination under subsection (1) (f), the commissioner of investigation and mediation must consider the factors referred to in section 25 (3).

If the commissioner of investigation and mediation dismisses a complaint or part of a complaint under subsection (1), that commissioner must inform the following persons of the decision in writing and give reasons for the decision:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the complainant;
the person against whom the complaint was made, if that person had been given notice of the complaint;
the deputy chief commissioner, if that commissioner is not already a party.

subsection.subsectiontext: Commissioner of investigation and mediation, a human rights officer or any person appointed, engaged or retained under section 17 may assist the parties to a complaint, through mediation and other means, to achieve a settlement.

Subject to section 40, a member of the commission, a human rights officer or any person appointed, engaged or retained under section 17 must not disclose any information concerning the terms of a settlement agreement provided to the commission under subsection (2) that would identify a party to the agreement unless that party consents to the release.

subsection.subsectiontext: If the terms of a settlement agreement have been provided to the commission under section 29 or 35 (1.4), a party to the agreement alleging there has been a breach of that agreement may file the agreement with the chair of the tribunal.

A settlement agreement filed under subsection (1) may be enforced in the same manner as an order of the tribunal under this Code but only to the extent that the terms of the agreement are within the powers of the tribunal to make an order under this Code.
The right to file a settlement agreement under subsection (1) cannot be waived.
A provision of a settlement agreement that purports to waive the right to file the agreement under subsection (1) is void.

subsection.subsectiontext: The British Columbia Human Rights Tribunal is established consisting of at least 3 full time members and not more than 6 part time members appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council must designate one of the full time members as chair of the tribunal.
Subject to subsections (3.1) and (4), members appointed under subsection (1) hold office for a term of 5 years.
If a member is absent or incapacitated the Lieutenant Governor in Council may appoint a temporary substitute member to act during the absence or incapacity.
On the first appointment of full time members of the tribunal under this section

paragraph.paragraphtext: one member is to be appointed for a term of 3 years, and
one member is to be appointed for a term of 4 years.

subsection.subsectiontext: A member of the tribunal is eligible to be reappointed for one additional term of 5 years.

subsection.subsectiontext: The British Columbia Human Rights Tribunal is established consisting of the members appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council.
The Lieutenant Governor in Council must designate one of the members as chair of the tribunal.
Subject to subsection (4), members appointed under subsection (1) hold office for a term of up to 5 years.

subsection.subsectiontext: A complaint referred to the tribunal under section 26 (1) (c) or 28.1 (3) (a) is to be heard by

subsection.subsectiontext: If a panel is designated under subsection (1) (b), the chair must designate one of the members of the panel to preside.
A member or panel has, for the purposes of this Act,

paragraph.paragraphtext: the protection and privileges of a commissioner under section 12 of the Inquiry Act, and
the powers of a commissioner under sections 15 and 16 of that Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: A member of the tribunal who resigns or whose appointment to the tribunal terminates may continue to act as a member in a hearing that has begun until an order is made under section 37 regarding the complaint.

subsection.subsectiontext: Subject to this Code and the regulations, the tribunal may make rules respecting the practice and procedure for the conduct of pre-hearing matters and hearings the tribunal considers necessary to facilitate just and timely resolution of complaints.
Without limiting subsection (1), the tribunal may make rules as follows:

paragraph.paragraphtext: requiring the parties to attend a pre-hearing conference in order to discuss issues relating to a complaint and the possibility of simplifying or disposing of issues;
respecting disclosure of evidence, including but not limited to pre-hearing disclosure and pre-hearing examination of a party on oath or solemn affirmation or by affidavit;

specifying the form of notice to be given to a party by another party or by the tribunal requiring a party to diligently pursue a complaint and the time within which and the manner in which the party must respond to the notice;
respecting service of notices and orders, including substituted service;
requiring a party to provide an address for service or delivery of notices and orders;
providing that a party's address of record is to be treated as an address for service.

subsection.subsectiontext: In order to facilitate the hearing of a complaint, a member or panel, on their own initiative or on application of a party, may make any order for which a rule could be made under subsection (1) or (1.1).
A member of the tribunal or any person engaged or retained under section 33 (2) may assist the parties to a complaint, through mediation and other means, to achieve a settlement.
The terms of each settlement agreement entered into in respect of a complaint must be provided to the commission and section 30 applies.

Subject to section 40, a member of the tribunal or any person engaged or retained under section 33 must not disclose any information concerning the terms of a settlement agreement provided to the tribunal under subsection (1.4) of this section that would identify a party to the agreement unless that party consents to the release.
A member or panel must give the parties the opportunity to be represented by counsel, to present relevant evidence, to cross examine witnesses and to make submissions.

A member or panel may receive and accept on oath, by affidavit or otherwise, evidence and information that the member or panel considers necessary and appropriate, whether or not the evidence or information would be admissible in a court of law.
A member or panel may hear 2 or more complaints together if the member or panel determines that hearing them together is fair and reasonable in the circumstances.

A member or panel may sever 2 or more complaints joined by the commissioner of investigation and mediation under section 21 (6) if the member or panel determines that severance is fair and reasonable in the circumstances.

subsection.subsectiontext: The deputy chief commissioner may require the tribunal to add the deputy chief commissioner as a party to a hearing under section 35.

A member or panel may, on the terms specified by the member or panel, allow any person or group of persons to intervene in the complaint, whether or not that person or group would be affected by an order made by the member or panel under section 37.

change.changenote: Section 37 (3) to (6) BEFORE amended by 2002-62-19, effective March 31, 2003 (BC Reg 79/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: An order made under subsection (2) may require the person against whom the order is made to provide the deputy chief commissioner or any other person designated in the order with information respecting the implementation of the order.

The member or panel may award costs against a party to a complaint that, in the opinion of the panel or member, has engaged in improper conduct during the course of the investigation or the hearing of the complaint.
A decision or order of the member or panel is a decision or order of the tribunal for the purposes of this Code.
The member or panel must inform the following persons in writing of the decision made under this section and give reasons for the decision:

paragraph.paragraphtext: the parties;
any intervenor allowed to participate in the hearing under section 36;
if not already a party, the deputy chief commissioner.

change.changenote: Section 38 BEFORE amended by 2002-62-20, effective March 31, 2003 (BC Reg 79/2003).

subsection.subsectiontext: Until an order made under section 37 (2) (c) or (d) (i) has been fully implemented, any party may apply to the tribunal for a modification of that order on the grounds that the order is no longer appropriate because of unforeseen circumstances.
An application under subsection (1) is to be considered by a member of the tribunal designated by the chair.
The designated member may vary or rescind the order after determining that the order

paragraph.paragraphtext: has not been fully implemented, and
is no longer appropriate because of unforeseen circumstances.

subsection.subsectiontext: In varying an order under subsection (3), the designated member may exercise any of the powers under section 37 (2) (a), (c) or (d).

The deputy chief commissioner may file an order made under section 37 (2) (d) only with the consent of

paragraph.paragraphtext: the complainant, if the complaint was filed on behalf of a group or class of persons, or
the person in whose favour the order is made in any other case.

subsection.subsectiontext: An order filed under subsection (1) has the same force and effect, and all proceedings may be taken on it, as if it were a judgment of the Supreme Court.
If the deputy chief commissioner files an order under subsection (1), that commissioner may take steps to enforce the order under subsection (3).

subsection.subsectiontext: In this section:

definition.def: means the Human Rights Act, S.B.C. 1984, c. 22, as it read on December 31, 1996;
means the Human Rights Code as it reads after December 31, 1996.

subsection.subsectiontext: If, before January 1, 1997, a complaint had been made under section 11 of the former Act, and no action concerning the complaint had been taken under section 14 of the former Act, the complaint is deemed to have been made under section 21 of the present Act.
A person who had been assigned to investigate a complaint under the former Act on December 31, 1996 is deemed to have been

paragraph.paragraphtext: designated as a human rights officer under section 23 (1) of the present Act, and
assigned to investigate the complaint under section 23 (2) of the present Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: If, before January 1, 1997, the chair of the British Columbia Council of Human Rights had referred a complaint to that council under section 14 (1) (a) of the former Act, the council has the same power to discontinue the complaint that the council had before January 1, 1997, and in relation to that complaint, sections 14 and 15 of the former Act remain in force despite their repeal.

If, in exercising its powers under subsection (4), the British Columbia Council of Human Rights decides that a complaint should not be discontinued, the complaint is deemed to be referred to the Human Rights Tribunal for a hearing under section 26 (1) (c) of the present Act.

If, before January 1, 1997, the chair of the British Columbia Council of Human Rights had referred a complaint to that council under section 14 (1) (a) of the former Act, and the council determined that the complaint should not be discontinued but no action has been taken by the chair under section 14 (1) (d) of that Act, the complaint is deemed to have been referred to the Human Rights Tribunal for a hearing under section 26 (1) (c) of the present Act.

If, before January 1, 1997, the chair of the British Columbia Council of Human Rights had designated a member of that council to receive submissions, in respect of a complaint, under section 14 (1) (d) of the former Act, and that member

paragraph.paragraphtext: had not, on December 31, 1996, received any submissions in respect of the complaint, the complaint is deemed to have been referred to the Human Rights Tribunal for a hearing under section 26 (1) (c) of the present Act, and

had, on December 31, 1996, received submissions in respect of the complaint but had not dismissed the complaint or made an order referred to in section 14 (1) (d) of the former Act, that member continues to have the same power to receive submissions, to dismiss the complaint or to make an order in respect of the complaint that the member had before January 1, 1997, and in relation to that complaint, sections 14, 15, 16, 17, 18 and 22 of the former Act remain in force despite their repeal.

subsection.subsectiontext: Nothing in this Act affects an order made, before January 1, 1997, by a member of the British Columbia Council of Human Rights under section 14 (1) (d) of the former Act.

subsection.subsectiontext: The deputy chief commissioner or any party aggrieved by the dismissal of all or part of a complaint under section 27 (1) may, within 60 days of being notified of the dismissal, apply to the chair of the tribunal for a review of that dismissal.

The review is to be conducted by a member of the tribunal designated by the chair and is to be based only on the information that was before the commissioner of investigation and mediation under section 27 (1).
If the member of the tribunal conducting the review determines that a complaint or part of a complaint should not have been dismissed under section 27 (1), the member may

paragraph.paragraphtext: refer the complaint or that part of the complaint to the tribunal for a hearing, or
refer the complaint or that part of the complaint back to the commissioner of investigation and mediation to be dealt with by that commissioner on the terms that the member directs.

subsection.subsectiontext: The deputy chief commissioner must be notified of the review and must be given an opportunity to make submissions at the review, whether or not that commissioner is a party to the complaint.
